Extracting statistics for features of a vector file form a multi-band raster file

Case Study

You have a raster multi-band file containing the values of an index (e.g., EVI) for multiple dates, and a vector file with areas from which you wish to either:

  1. Extract the time serie for each pixel contained in polygon ;
  2. Compute summary statistics on the values of the pixels of each polygon, for each date/band of the raster

Solution

You can use sprawl::extract_rast to quickly extract both the single-pixel time series, and the statistics for each polygon and date

Example

First of all, open the input raster containing the time series, and of the input vector file containing the polygons (i.e., the ROIs) for which you want the values.

# Here I'm using test datasets accessed on the filesystem, but on common usage it would as 
# simple as `in_polys <- read_vect("D:/mypath/myfolder/lc_polys.shp"")

library(raster)
library(sprawl)


in_polys <- read_vect(system.file("extdata","lc_polys.shp", package = "sprawl.data"))
in_rast  <- stack(system.file("extdata", "sprawl_EVItest.tif", package = "sprawl.data"))

Now, in in_polys we have a vector with 13 polygons:

## Simple feature collection with 13 features and 4 fields
## geometry type:  POLYGON
## dimension:      XY
## bbox:           xmin: 120.1778 ymin: 15.15353 xmax: 121.3394 ymax: 16.09343
## epsg (SRID):    4326
## proj4string:    +proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs
## # A tibble: 13 x 5
##       id       lc_type category sup_catego          geometry
##    <dbl>         <chr>    <chr>      <chr> <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  1     1      forest_1   Forest Vegetation <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  2     2      forest_2   Forest Vegetation <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  3     3       urban_1    Other      Other <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  4     4    cropland_1 Cropland Vegetation <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  5     5    cropland_2 Cropland Vegetation <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  6     6      forest_3   Forest Vegetation <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  7     7    reiver_bed    Other      Other <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  8     8    cropland_3 Cropland Vegetation <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
##  9     9  urban_2_part    Other      Other <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
## 10    10 sparsfor_part   Forest Vegetation <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
## 11    11         water    Other      Other <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
## 12    12    small_feat    Other      Other <S3: sfc_POLYGON>
## 13    13      out_feat    Other      Other <S3: sfc_POLYGON>

, and in in_rast a raster time series with 46 bands:

## class       : RasterStack 
## dimensions  : 447, 331, 147957, 46  (nrow, ncol, ncell, nlayers)
## resolution  : 231.6564, 231.6564  (x, y)
## extent      : 12897004, 12973683, 1685995, 1789545  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
## coord. ref. : +proj=sinu +lon_0=0 +x_0=0 +y_0=0 +a=6371007.181 +b=6371007.181 +units=m +no_defs 
## names       : sprawl_EVItest.1, sprawl_EVItest.2, sprawl_EVItest.3, sprawl_EVItest.4, sprawl_EVItest.5, sprawl_EVItest.6, sprawl_EVItest.7, sprawl_EVItest.8, sprawl_EVItest.9, sprawl_EVItest.10, sprawl_EVItest.11, sprawl_EVItest.12, sprawl_EVItest.13, sprawl_EVItest.14, sprawl_EVItest.15, ... 
## min values  :             -621,             -813,             -834,             -559,             -323,             -680,             -557,            -1886,             -861,              -884,              -917,              -550,              -540,             -1948,             -1912, ... 
## max values  :             9971,             9167,             9307,             9988,             8706,             9767,             9740,             9939,             8452,              9358,              9983,              8504,              9858,              9976,              9980, ...

Let’s have a look at some bands:

plot_rast(in_rast[[2:7]], limits = c(0,7000), in_poly = in_polys)

To extract the values of pixels included in each polygon, you can then use simply:

extracted_values <- extract_rast(in_rast, in_polys)

extracted values is a list containing two components:

  • extracted_values$alldata contains the values for each extracted pixel, along with information extracted from the vector file. Additionally, the number of pixels extracted from each polygon is shown in the N_PIX column, and an identifier to each pixel in the N column
## Simple feature collection with 6 features and 9 fields
## geometry type:  POINT
## dimension:      XY
## bbox:           xmin: 12918200 ymin: 1754797 xmax: 12919360 ymax: 1754797
## epsg (SRID):    NA
## proj4string:    +proj=sinu +lon_0=0 +x_0=0 +y_0=0 +a=6371007.181 +b=6371007.181 +units=m +no_defs
##    lc_type band_n        band_name N_PIX N value id category sup_catego
## 1 forest_1      1 sprawl_EVItest.1    61 1  4454  1   Forest Vegetation
## 2 forest_1      1 sprawl_EVItest.1    61 2  4260  1   Forest Vegetation
## 3 forest_1      1 sprawl_EVItest.1    61 3  4224  1   Forest Vegetation
## 4 forest_1      1 sprawl_EVItest.1    61 4  4344  1   Forest Vegetation
## 5 forest_1      1 sprawl_EVItest.1    61 5  4489  1   Forest Vegetation
## 6 forest_1      1 sprawl_EVItest.1    61 6  4970  1   Forest Vegetation
##                         geometry
## 1 POINT(12918200.975691 17547...
## 2 POINT(12918432.632049 17547...
## 3 POINT(12918664.288407 17547...
## 4 POINT(12918895.944765 17547...
## 5 POINT(12919127.601123 17547...
## 6 POINT(12919359.257481 17547...
  • extracted_values$statdata contains instead the statistics for each polygon and band. By default, average, standard deviation, minimum, maximum and median are computed (see the help of the function)
## Simple feature collection with 6 features and 12 fields
## geometry type:  POLYGON
## dimension:      XY
## bbox:           xmin: 12918420 ymin: 1752797 xmax: 12920610 ymax: 1755103
## epsg (SRID):    NA
## proj4string:    +proj=sinu +lon_0=0 +x_0=0 +y_0=0 +a=6371007.181 +b=6371007.181 +units=m +no_defs
##    lc_type band_n        band_name N_PIX      avg  med       sd  min  max
## 1 forest_1      1 sprawl_EVItest.1    61 4830.820 4747 540.6097 3731 5987
## 2 forest_1      2 sprawl_EVItest.2    61 4605.131 4648 510.8426 3665 5547
## 3 forest_1      3 sprawl_EVItest.3    61 4837.902 4834 557.4429 3640 5827
## 4 forest_1      4 sprawl_EVItest.4    61 4484.984 4411 473.7452 3285 5275
## 5 forest_1      5 sprawl_EVItest.5    61 4284.197 4237 498.7366 3469 5318
## 6 forest_1      6 sprawl_EVItest.6    61 4374.525 4302 471.1914 3317 5363
##   id category sup_catego                       geometry
## 1  1   Forest Vegetation POLYGON((12918415.6569245 1...
## 2  1   Forest Vegetation POLYGON((12918415.6569245 1...
## 3  1   Forest Vegetation POLYGON((12918415.6569245 1...
## 4  1   Forest Vegetation POLYGON((12918415.6569245 1...
## 5  1   Forest Vegetation POLYGON((12918415.6569245 1...
## 6  1   Forest Vegetation POLYGON((12918415.6569245 1...

These results can be easily used for performing further analysis or plotting (coming soon !)
